federalContext.law: GENIUS Act (Guiding and Establishing National Innovation for U.S. Stablecoins Act)
federalContext.summary: The GENIUS Act was signed into law on July 18, 2025. It establishes the first broad federal framework for payment stablecoins, including reserve backing, redemption, supervision, and issuer requirements, while still allowing certain state pathways when standards are substantially similar.

pendingFederalBills.title: Digital Asset Market Clarity Act of 2025 (CLARITY Act)
pendingFederalBills.what: Would create a broader federal market-structure framework for digital asset spot markets and regulatory jurisdiction.
pendingFederalBills.latest: Latest action (September 18, 2025): received in the Senate, read twice, and referred to the Senate Banking Committee.

pendingFederalBills.title: Anti-CBDC Surveillance State Act
pendingFederalBills.what: Would limit the Federal Reserve from issuing a U.S. CBDC directly to individuals and from using a CBDC for monetary policy implementation.
pendingFederalBills.latest: Latest action (July 17, 2025): passed House 219-210; Senate has not enacted a corresponding final measure.

pendingFederalBills.title: Digital Asset Tax Reform Bill (Senate)
pendingFederalBills.what: Would establish digital-asset-related federal tax treatment updates, including de minimis treatment discussions and related reporting/tax mechanics.
pendingFederalBills.latest: Latest action (June 30, 2025): introduced in the Senate and referred to the Senate Finance Committee.

majorStateDevelopments.title: DFAL licensing rollout
majorStateDevelopments.what: California's DFAL licensing and compliance framework for covered digital asset business activity.
majorStateDevelopments.status: Implementation watch (not a pending bill): DFPI rulemaking/implementation remains active ahead of the July 1, 2026 licensure date.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Most recent posture: DFAL remains in implementation mode under DFPI with operative date tied to 2026 licensure.

majorStateDevelopments.title: HB 1039 - State cryptocurrency reserve
majorStateDevelopments.what: Would establish and govern a Florida Strategic Cryptocurrency Reserve.
majorStateDevelopments.status: Pending bill: filed in House, referred to committees, and received first reading on January 13, 2026.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Latest action: House first reading (January 13, 2026) after committee referrals.

majorStateDevelopments.title: SB 1044 - Virtual currency property tax exemption
majorStateDevelopments.what: Would exempt virtual currency from property taxation, conditional on voter approval of a constitutional amendment.
majorStateDevelopments.status: Pending bill: prefiled for Arizona's 2026 second regular session and introduced in the Senate.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Current posture: introduced text published for 2026 session with conditional enactment language.

majorStateDevelopments.title: HB 2232 - Cryptocurrency kiosk licensure
majorStateDevelopments.what: Would require DIFI licensure and compliance controls for cryptocurrency kiosk operators.
majorStateDevelopments.status: Pending bill: introduced in Arizona House (2026 second regular session).
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Current posture: introduced bill text sets January 1, 2027 licensure requirement for kiosk operators.

majorStateDevelopments.title: S4728A - NY crypto/blockchain study task force
majorStateDevelopments.what: Would have created a state cryptocurrency and blockchain study task force.
majorStateDevelopments.status: Not pending: vetoed in the 2025-2026 session.
majorStateDevelopments.latest: Current posture: bill page marks S4728A as vetoed by the governor.

NY.name: New York
NY.summary: New York has one of the strictest crypto regulatory regimes. Most digital asset business activity touching New York or New York residents requires a BitLicense or trust charter, and NYDFS has specific USD-backed stablecoin issuance guidance.
keyLaws: NYDFS Industry Letter on USD-Backed Stablecoins (June 8, 2022)
NY.recentDevelopments: NYDFS continues issuing digital-asset-focused supervisory and industry letters, with stablecoin reserve and redemption expectations remaining central.

CA.name: California
CA.summary: California's Digital Financial Assets Law (DFAL) establishes a broad licensing and compliance framework for digital asset business activity. Covered entities must be licensed by, or have applied with, DFPI by July 1, 2026.
keyLaws: AB 1934 (2024) - licensure timeline extension to July 1, 2026
CA.recentDevelopments: DFPI continued DFAL rulemaking in 2025 and has already brought enforcement actions against kiosk operators under DFAL provisions.

WY.name: Wyoming
WY.summary: Wyoming remains one of the most crypto-forward jurisdictions in the US. It created a state stable token legal framework and continues operating specialized digital-asset-focused banking structures such as SPDIs.
keyLaws: Wyoming Stable Token Act (SF0127; Enrolled Act 85, 2023)
WY.recentDevelopments: Wyoming stable token administration and related commission policy materials have continued to be published; the SPDI framework remains active.

TX.name: Texas
TX.summary: Texas has an active digital asset policy posture and enacted SB 21 in 2025, creating the Texas Strategic Bitcoin Reserve framework. Texas also has statutory operational requirements for qualifying digital asset service providers.
keyLaws: SB 21 (89R, 2025) - Texas Strategic Bitcoin Reserve and Investment Act
Texas Finance Code Chapter 160 - Digital Asset Service Providers
TX.recentDevelopments: SB 21 was signed by the Governor on June 20, 2025 and took effect immediately according to bill history.

FL.name: Florida
FL.summary: Florida uses a money-services framework that explicitly references digital assets in key definitions and transmitter obligations. It also enacted 2023 legislation excluding CBDCs from the UCC definition of money.
keyLaws: SB 7054 (2023) - CBDC treatment under Florida UCC
FL.recentDevelopments: HB 1039 (2026 session), which would establish a state cryptocurrency reserve framework, has been filed and referred in committee.

WA.name: Washington
WA.summary: Washington generally regulates digital asset businesses through its Uniform Money Services Act and related DFI policy statements. Digital asset activities commonly trigger licensing and disclosure duties under state money transmission rules.
keyLaws: Chapter 19.230 RCW - Uniform Money Services Act
DFI policy statement regarding digital asset kiosks (2024)
WA.recentDevelopments: DFI has continued active enforcement and supervision actions involving digital-asset-related operations.

LA.name: Louisiana
LA.summary: Louisiana has a dedicated digital asset business activity framework administered by the Office of Financial Institutions. Entities conducting covered digital asset business activity in Louisiana generally need to follow the state's licensing regime.
LA.recentDevelopments: Louisiana OFI has continued posting annual legislative and licensing updates specific to digital asset business activity.

AZ.name: Arizona
AZ.summary: Arizona has moved on multiple digital-asset bills and enacted HB2749 in 2025 to establish a Bitcoin and digital assets reserve fund structure tied to unclaimed-property-related flows. Other reserve-focused proposals have faced vetoes, so the framework remains mixed.
keyLaws: HB2749 (2025) - Bitcoin and Digital Assets Reserve Fund
AZ.recentDevelopments: SB1373 and SB1025 were vetoed in 2025 while HB2749 advanced, reflecting an active but still evolving policy direction.

NH.name: New Hampshire
NH.summary: New Hampshire is generally viewed as policy-forward on digital assets, but stablecoin-specific state licensing remains limited and model-dependent.
keyLaws: State-level digital asset policy proposals and enactments (including treasury and investment activity)
NH.recentDevelopments: Legislative and treasury-related digital asset developments continue, but stablecoin-specific supervisory structure remains limited.

NE.name: Nebraska
NE.summary: Nebraska created a charter path for digital asset depositories under the Nebraska Financial Innovation Act, giving it one of the clearer state-level structures for digital-asset banking operations.
NE.recentDevelopments: Nebraska officials announced a first-in-nation digital asset bank charter in 2025 under the state framework.

NJ.name: New Jersey
NJ.summary: New Jersey generally operates through existing money transmitter and broader financial-services laws without a complete stablecoin-specific framework. Companies still require model-specific licensing analysis.
NJ.recentDevelopments: Regulatory clarity remains tied to pending state proposals and the rollout of federal GENIUS Act implementation.

IL.name: Illinois
IL.summary: Illinois primarily applies existing money transmission and financial-services rules to digital asset businesses. There is no comprehensive stablecoin-specific licensing framework currently in force.
IL.recentDevelopments: State-level developments continue, but market participants still rely heavily on federal and existing-state-law interpretation.

PA.name: Pennsylvania
PA.summary: Pennsylvania does not currently have a full stablecoin-specific statutory framework. Most treatment remains under general money transmission and related financial regulation.
PA.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law has been enacted.

MA.name: Massachusetts
MA.summary: Massachusetts does not have a dedicated stablecoin licensing regime and generally regulates through existing banking, money transmission, and securities authorities.
keyLaws: Money transmission and banking supervision framework
MA.recentDevelopments: Policy development remains incremental; no fully separate stablecoin statute is in force.

HI.name: Hawaii
HI.summary: Hawaii has transitioned from more restrictive approaches toward pilot and guidance-based pathways, but stablecoin-specific permanent rules remain limited.
keyLaws: Digital Currency Innovation Lab and follow-on guidance
HI.recentDevelopments: The state continues evaluating permanent framework options after pilot-era initiatives.

NV.name: Nevada
NV.summary: Nevada has maintained a generally innovation-friendly blockchain posture and does not currently impose a dedicated stablecoin statute.
keyLaws: State blockchain-related legislation and general financial-services regulation
NV.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific state licensing framework has been added.

UT.name: Utah
UT.summary: Utah is generally regarded as innovation-forward with regulatory sandbox history and blockchain policy activity, though it does not yet have a dedicated stablecoin statute.
keyLaws: Utah regulatory sandbox and digital innovation initiatives
UT.recentDevelopments: Utah continues digital asset and fintech policy activity through legislative and regulator channels.

CO.name: Colorado
CO.summary: Colorado has signaled digital asset openness through policy experimentation and public-sector adoption initiatives, without a dedicated stablecoin licensing regime.
keyLaws: State-level digital payment and blockchain initiatives
CO.recentDevelopments: Colorado remains active in digital-asset-adjacent policy and implementation discussions.

GA.name: Georgia
GA.summary: Georgia does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework and primarily applies general money transmission requirements.
GA.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law is currently in force.

OH.name: Ohio
OH.summary: Ohio does not yet have a comprehensive stablecoin-specific framework, and activity is generally governed by existing financial-services and money transmission rules.
keyLaws: Money transmission and related state financial statutes
OH.recentDevelopments: Policy interest continues, but stablecoin-specific statewide treatment remains unsettled.

VT.name: Vermont
VT.summary: Vermont has adopted modified money-transmission-style treatment that includes digital asset obligations, but not a standalone stablecoin code.
keyLaws: Modified money transmission framework with digital-asset provisions
VT.recentDevelopments: The state has continued refining its implementation posture under broader financial statutes.

DE.name: Delaware
DE.summary: Delaware is blockchain-aware through corporate law modernization but has not adopted a complete stablecoin-specific financial licensing regime.
keyLaws: Delaware General Corporation Law blockchain amendments
DE.recentDevelopments: Business-law-level support continues without a bespoke stablecoin statute.

DC.name: District of Columbia
DC.summary: DC uses a money transmission framework and closely tracks federal digital asset developments. There is no independent, comprehensive stablecoin code specific to DC.
DC.recentDevelopments: Federal implementation developments are likely to drive practical compliance expectations in DC.

AK.name: Alaska
AK.summary: Alaska does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin law and primarily relies on general money-services and financial regulation.
AK.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statutory framework is currently in force.

MI.name: Michigan
MI.summary: Michigan currently relies on existing money transmission and financial services frameworks for most digital asset activity.
MI.recentDevelopments: No comprehensive stablecoin-specific statewide regime has been enacted.

NC.name: North Carolina
NC.summary: North Carolina does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework; general money transmission and consumer finance rules apply.
NC.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin statute is currently in force.

VA.name: Virginia
VA.summary: Virginia generally governs digital asset businesses under existing financial services and money transmission rules.

MD.name: Maryland
MD.summary: Maryland does not currently operate a dedicated stablecoin framework and relies on existing money transmission requirements.
MD.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin law is currently in force.

OK.name: Oklahoma
OK.summary: Oklahoma currently applies general financial-services rules and money transmission obligations where applicable.
OK.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin framework has been enacted.

KY.name: Kentucky
KY.summary: Kentucky has pursued selected crypto-industry-friendly measures while still relying on baseline financial-services rules for broader activity.
keyLaws: State-level digital asset and mining-related policy initiatives
KY.recentDevelopments: Kentucky continues to be viewed as comparatively crypto-supportive in policy tone.

TN.name: Tennessee
TN.summary: Tennessee has no dedicated stablecoin licensing statute and generally relies on existing money transmission rules.
TN.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin framework has been enacted.

SC.name: South Carolina
SC.summary: South Carolina does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statute and generally relies on standard financial services regulation.
keyLaws: General financial services and transmission oversight
SC.recentDevelopments: No major state-level stablecoin framework currently in force.

OR.name: Oregon
OR.summary: Oregon currently relies on general money transmission and financial-services regulation for most digital asset activity.
OR.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin law has been enacted.

MN.name: Minnesota
MN.summary: Minnesota does not currently have a bespoke stablecoin statute and generally uses existing money transmission regulation.
MN.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework has been enacted.

WI.name: Wisconsin
WI.summary: Wisconsin currently applies standard financial regulation and money transmission concepts to digital asset businesses where relevant.
WI.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin licensing framework is currently in force.

IA.name: Iowa
IA.summary: Iowa does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin framework and generally governs under existing money-services rules.
IA.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin law has been enacted.

IN.name: Indiana
IN.summary: Indiana currently relies on existing money transmission and financial regulation for digital asset activity.
IN.recentDevelopments: No dedicated statewide stablecoin framework has been enacted.

MO.name: Missouri
MO.summary: Missouri does not currently have a comprehensive stablecoin statute and generally applies existing financial-services rules.
MO.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide regime is currently in force.

AR.name: Arkansas
AR.summary: Arkansas has taken selected industry-supportive positions in digital asset policy, especially around mining-related operations. Stablecoin-specific licensing remains limited.
keyLaws: Arkansas digital asset and mining policy measures
AR.recentDevelopments: State policy remains relatively open in tone while broader federal implementation progresses.

KS.name: Kansas
KS.summary: Kansas has no dedicated stablecoin statutory regime and generally relies on existing money transmission rules.
KS.recentDevelopments: No major statewide stablecoin framework currently in force.

MS.name: Mississippi
MS.summary: Mississippi currently governs digital asset activity primarily under existing financial-services and money transmission concepts.
MS.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin licensing law has been enacted.

AL.name: Alabama
AL.summary: Alabama currently relies on existing money-services and financial licensing frameworks for digital asset activity.
keyLaws: Sale of checks / money services baseline rules
AL.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework has been enacted.

NM.name: New Mexico
NM.summary: New Mexico does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statute and generally uses money transmission and broader financial regulatory frameworks.
NM.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin framework currently in force.

CT.name: Connecticut
CT.summary: Connecticut has adopted money-transmission-style treatment with digital asset relevance, but has not enacted a fully independent stablecoin statute.
keyLaws: Money transmission framework with digital asset coverage
CT.recentDevelopments: Implementation remains tied to broader state financial-services regulation and federal changes.

WV.name: West Virginia
WV.summary: West Virginia currently has no dedicated stablecoin statute and generally relies on existing financial regulation.
WV.recentDevelopments: No major stablecoin-specific statewide framework is currently in force.

ND.name: North Dakota
ND.summary: North Dakota generally relies on existing money transmission and financial-services rules for digital asset businesses.
ND.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin statute has been enacted.

SD.name: South Dakota
SD.summary: South Dakota does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statute; businesses generally rely on standard financial and money services frameworks.
SD.recentDevelopments: No major statewide stablecoin licensing framework currently in force.

ID.name: Idaho
ID.summary: Idaho currently relies on existing money transmission and financial-services regulation for digital asset activity.
ID.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin framework has been enacted.

ME.name: Maine
ME.summary: Maine does not currently have a dedicated stablecoin statutory framework and generally relies on broader financial-services regulation.
ME.recentDevelopments: No major standalone stablecoin framework currently in force.

RI.name: Rhode Island
RI.summary: Rhode Island currently uses standard money transmission and financial regulation for most digital asset activity.
RI.recentDevelopments: No standalone stablecoin statute has been enacted.

MT.name: Montana
MT.summary: Montana is often viewed as lighter-touch for certain digital asset business models compared with many peer states, though firms should still perform model-specific licensing analysis.
keyLaws: Digital asset and business-law treatment under Montana statutes
MT.recentDevelopments: No dedicated stablecoin licensing framework has been added.
